title: SSCJC: Real World Depression Measurement
summary:
Key ideas:
- PANDA (Prescribing ANtiDepressants Appropriately) is the largest non-pharma antidepressant trial ever conducted and is designed to mimic “the real world”.
- Measuring real-world efficacy is especially important for antidepressant research because past studies have failed to match up with common sense.
- The study used patient-reported “uncertainty…about the possible benefit of an antidepressant” to select participants.
- The study showed only small to low-medium effect sizes for everything.
- The study’s finding of a 0.4 – 0.5 effect size on patient response closely matches another study’s finding of an 0.4 – 0.5 effect size on depressed mood.

Key learnings:
- It is really hard to measure antidepressant outcomes and all endpoints conflict with each other.
- Antidepressants do better on patient report than on depression tests.
- Patients care a lot less about smaller symptoms and more about feeling happy again.
- Targeted treatment with more typical vs. atypical depression could bring the effect size up.

Key questions:
- Can we really trust clinical trials that fail to match up with common sense?
- How can we measure antidepressant outcomes more accurately?
- Are our depression tests effective? How can we improve them?
- How can we prescribe antidepressants more confidently?
